SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to us.

Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

Name: George Arthur Hartwell
Address: 249 Broad Street, Regina, Saskatchewan.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? (Age 72, age old.)

Where did you set up housekeeping? Section 123, North of Loring, Saskatchewan.

How far was it to your nearest store? (High Mile)

How often could a visit be made to the store? About once in three weeks.

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?

Sugar, tea, syrup, dried apples, coal oil, baking powder, soda.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years?

In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lb bags

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour?

How much did you use graham flour?

Was flour milled locally? Yes

What other grain products did you use?

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge?

How did you grind it?

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) When did you first see enamel ware? Aluminum?
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

1882 to 1890 - Brown paper bags, kegs, and sacks.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g. winter or summer.

1883 Breakfast (Farridge - corn oat meal) hot bread and milk, tea, fried potatoes

Dinner - potatoes, wild game, salt pork, bread, tea.

Supper - Hot cakes, corn mush, dumplings, syrup, tea

Mother, Father, three sisters and myself (sisters all younger than myself)

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? .......

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

1882 - had roast beef, with a roly-poly pudding sparsely sprinkled with currents, potatoes.

Present: Our family along with Mr. and Mrs. John Stillborn and family of 1 boy and 5 girls (boy was the oldest - about 10 years of age).

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

One space of two weeks on boiled wheat that was to have been used for seed - the reason being that we ran short of supplies while Father was at the railhead in the early spring - high water prevented his return and Mother from getting out.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS
Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers associated with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

1892 to 1894 - Brown paper bags, kegs, and boxes.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner, and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate age of the children or summer.

1893 Breakfast (porridge - corn oat meal) hot bread and milk, tea, fried potatoes
Dinner - potatoes, wild game, salt pork, bread, tea.
Supper - Hot cakes, corn mush, dumplings, syrupy tea

Mother, Father, three sisters and myself (sisters all younger than myself)

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

1902 - had roast beef, with a roly-poly pudding separately sprinkled with currants.

Present: Our family along with Mr. and Mrs. John Stillborn and family of
1 boy and 5 girls (boy was the oldest - about 10 years of age).

19. Have you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

One sparse of two weeks on rolled wheat that was to have been used for seed - the reason being that we ran short of supplies while Father was at the railroad in the early spring high water prevented his return and Mother from getting out.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

There was very little variety in the early days.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

During the winter went to Pheasant Forks store by snow-shoe and dog team - about once a month for supplies.
